title: Ajanta Caves: History and Art - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Ajanta Cave Paintings and Buddhist Art

questions.question: Who discovered prehistoric rock paintings at Sohagihat in Mirzapur district in 1867-1868?
questions.explanation: Archibald Carlleyle of the Archaeological Survey of India discovered rock paintings at Sohagihat in the Mirzapur district of Uttar Pradesh in 1867 and 1868, which he thought dated from the Stone Age.

questions.question: What did J. Cockburn discover in 1881 in the Mirzapur region?
options: Fossilised rhinoceros bones and a painting of a rhinoceros hunted by three men
questions.explanation: In 1881, J. Cockburn found fossilised rhinoceros bones in the valley of the Ken River in the Mirzapur region as well as a painting of a rhinoceros hunted by three men in a shelter near Roap Village.

questions.question: Who led the excavations in 1924 on the banks of rivers Ravi and Indus?
options: Sir John Marshall, Rai Bahadur Daya Ram Sahni, Madho Sarup Vats, Rakhal Das Banerjee, and E. J. H. MacKay
questions.explanation: In 1924, Sir John Marshall, Rai Bahadur Daya Ram Sahni, Madho Sarup Vats, Rakhal Das Banerjee, and E. J. H. MacKay led excavations on the banks of the river Ravi and Indus, leading to the discovery of civilization thousands of years old.

questions.question: Which ancient Indian cave painting sites are mentioned as dating from 1st Century BCE to 7th Century CE?
options: Jogimara, Bagh, Badami, Sittanvasal, Armamalai and Ajanta
questions.explanation: The ancient Indian cave paintings dating from the 1st Century BCE to the 7th Century CE include frescos of Jogimara, Bagh, Badami, Sittanvasal, Armamalai and Ajanta.

questions.question: What is the main theme of Ajanta cave paintings?
options: The life of Buddha and Jataka narratives
questions.explanation: The main theme of Ajanta cave paintings is the life of Buddha and Jataka narratives, while Badami has Brahmanical-Hinduism themes and Sittanavasal has Jaina themes.

questions.question: How many caves are there in the Ajanta complex?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta complex has 29 caves, including an unfinished one. These caves were excavated in different periods from the 2nd century B.C. to 6th century A.D.

questions.question: What was the purpose of Ajanta as a Buddhist site?
options: A monastery where Buddhist monks lived, studied and held learned discussions
questions.explanation: Ajanta was a monastery where Buddhist monks lived, studied and held learned discussions. The purpose behind painting Buddha's life was to remind monks of their ideals and his hardships on the journey towards enlightenment.

questions.question: What are Ajanta paintings renowned for worldwide?
options: Their expressive faces, eyes and hand gestures
questions.explanation: Portrait faces at Ajanta are renowned worldwide for their expressive faces, eyes and hand gestures.

questions.question: What is Shadanga in the context of Ajanta paintings?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta painters followed the Shadanga, or six paramount rules of art, yet gave free rein to their imagination.

questions.question: Which pigment was imported for blue color in Ajanta paintings?
questions.explanation: Lapis lazuli was imported for blue color. Other pigments were locally sourced, including kaolin chalk for white, lamp soot for black, glauconite for green, and ochre for yellow, red and brown.

questions.question: What was used for white color in Ajanta paintings?
questions.explanation: Kaolin chalk was used for white color in Ajanta paintings. All pigments were derived from natural water-soluble substances.

questions.question: What was the source of black color in Ajanta paintings?
questions.explanation: Lamp soot (lamp black) was used for black color in Ajanta paintings.

questions.question: Which substance was used for green color at Ajanta?
questions.explanation: Glauconite was used for green color. It is a naturally occurring mineral that provided the green pigment for Ajanta paintings.

questions.question: What was the source of yellow, red and brown colors at Ajanta?
questions.explanation: Ochre was used for yellow, and red and brown came from local iron-rich clay. These were all naturally available materials.

questions.question: When were the pigments added during the Ajanta painting process?
options: Only after the undercoat was completely dry
questions.explanation: The pigments were thickened with glue and added only after the undercoat was completely dry, which is characteristic of tempera technique.

questions.question: What subjects are depicted in Ajanta paintings besides Buddha's life?
options: Apsaras, Gandharvas, Gods, royal personages, paupers, courtesans, monks, animals, birds, and flora
questions.explanation: Ajanta paintings depict Apsaras and Gandharvas, Gods and Goddesses, royal personages and paupers, courtesans and monks, animals and birds, wild and pet animals, trees-vines-creepers-bushes, showing familiarity with contemporary life.

questions.question: Which famous Ajanta painting depicts a Bodhisattva holding a lotus?
questions.explanation: Padmapani Bodhisattva is one of the masterpieces at Ajanta. The name means 'lotus in hand' (Padma = lotus, Pani = hand), referring to the blue lotus blossom in his right hand.

questions.question: Who discovered the Ajanta caves in 1819?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta caves came to light in 1819 when a British Army officer John Smith accidentally discovered the entrance to Cave No. 10 deep within the tangled undergrowth while hunting a tiger.

questions.question: In what period were the Ajanta caves excavated?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta caves had been excavated in different periods spanning from 2nd century B.C. to 6th century A.D. in a horse-shoe-shaped bend of rock surface.

questions.question: What are Chaityagrihas at Ajanta?
options: Prayer halls where religious discourses were conducted
questions.explanation: Five caves at Ajanta (cave no. 9, 10, 19, 26, and 29) are Chaityagrihas where religious discourses were conducted. The rest are viharas or living quarters for the monks.

questions.question: Which Ajanta caves have discernible murals today?
questions.explanation: Though all the caves had been painted, today only caves 1, 2, 9, 11, 16 and 17 have discernible murals; the rest have been lost due to neglect and the ravages of time.

questions.question: What does the ceiling decoration at Ajanta invariably consist of?
options: Decorative patterns, geometrical as well as floral
questions.explanation: The ceiling decoration at Ajanta invariably consists of decorative patterns, geometrical as well as floral.

questions.question: What does the variety and detail in Ajanta paintings suggest about the monks?
options: Before they renounced the world, they had known it and its processes well
They were trained artists from birth
questions.explanation: The variety of subjects, details in paintings, dexterity in rock cutting and architectural finesse suggest that before they renounced it, the monks had known the world and its processes well.

questions.question: What is the size of the Padmapani Bodhisattva mural?
questions.explanation: The Padmapani Bodhisattva mural in Cave 1 at Ajanta is 174 cm, making it a lifesize mural and a marvel of Indian painting.

questions.question: What adorns the Padmapani Bodhisattva in the famous mural?
options: Pearls, amethyst, lapis lazuli and other gems, with a magnificent crown
questions.explanation: The Padmapani Bodhisattva is adorned with classic Indian jewellry fit for a man of noble birth, including pearls, amethyst, lapis lazuli and other gems, with a magnificent crown on his head.

questions.question: What does the blue lotus blossom in Padmapani's hand represent?
questions.explanation: The blue lotus blossom in Padmapani Bodhisattva's right hand represents his spiritual awakening. This is why he is named Padmapani (Padma = lotus blossom, Pani = hand).

questions.question: What does the crown on Padmapani Bodhisattva signify?
questions.explanation: The magnificent crown on Padmapani Bodhisattva's head signifies his royal lineage, indicating he was of noble birth before his spiritual path.

questions.question: How are the eyes of Padmapani Bodhisattva depicted?
questions.explanation: The eyes of Padmapani Bodhisattva are lowered in a meditative state, contributing to the calm and spiritual nature of the figure.

questions.question: What was the first step in creating the surface for Ajanta murals?
options: Creating an almost plane surface on the rockface with chisel and hammer
questions.explanation: The craftsmen first created an almost plane surface on the rockface with a chisel and hammer before preparing the layers for painting.

questions.question: What was used in the first rough layer applied to the rock surface at Ajanta?
options: Earth mixed with rock-grit or sand, vegetable fibres, paddy husk, grass
questions.explanation: The surface was prepared with a rough layer of earth mixed with rock-grit or sand, vegetable fibres, paddy husk, and grass.

questions.question: What was applied as the second coat over the rough layer at Ajanta?
options: Mud mixed with fine rock powder or sand and fine fibrous vegetable material
questions.explanation: A second coat of mud mixed with fine rock powder or sand and fine fibrous vegetable material was applied over the rough first layer.

questions.question: What was the final finishing layer applied before painting at Ajanta?
options: A thin coat of lime wash
questions.explanation: The surface was finally finished with a thin coat of lime wash, creating a smooth white surface ready for painting.

questions.question: What was done after the lime wash surface was prepared at Ajanta?
options: The wall was left to age
Outlines were drawn boldly then spaces were filled with requisite colours
questions.explanation: Over the lime wash surface, outlines were drawn boldly then the spaces were filled with requisite colours.

questions.question: What range of colors did Ajanta painters have at their disposal?
options: A limited range from natural sources: red and yellow ochre, terra verte, lime, kaolin, gypsum, lamp black and lapis lazuli
questions.explanation: The Ajanta painters had a limited range of colours: red and yellow ochre, terra verte, lime, kaolin, gypsum, lamp black and lapis lazuli. Some vegetable colours were also used.

questions.question: What type of colors were also used besides mineral pigments at Ajanta?
questions.explanation: Besides mineral pigments, some vegetable colours have also been used in Ajanta paintings.

questions.question: What is terra verte in the context of Ajanta pigments?
questions.explanation: Terra verte is a green earth pigment that was among the limited range of colours available to Ajanta painters.

questions.question: What masterpiece paintings are mentioned from Ajanta?
options: Padmapani Bodhisattva, Yashodhara and Rahul, Chhadantajataka, The Cruel Brahmin, Shibijataka Vessantara, Flight of Nanda
questions.explanation: Famous Ajanta masterpieces include Padmapani Bodhisattva, Yashodhara and Rahul, Chhadantajataka, The Cruel Brahmin, Shibijataka Vessantara, and the Flight of Nanda.

questions.question: What animals are depicted in prehistoric rock paintings in India?
options: Animals shown as Gods, along with human figures hunting, at war, and celebrating
questions.explanation: Prehistoric rock paintings show human figures hunting a beast, at war, carrying clubs and projectiles, celebrating victory with dance, and animal figures in movement, often representing animals as Gods.

questions.question: What was found at excavation sites on the banks of Ravi and Indus in 1924?
options: Seals, coins, statuettes, and terracottas with animal figures painted or carved
questions.explanation: The seals, coins, statuettes, and terracottas found at these sites have animal figures painted or carved, indicating an ancient civilization thousands of years old.

questions.question: What purpose did painting Buddha's life at Ajanta serve for the monks?
options: To remind monks of their ideals and the hardships Buddha faced on his journey towards enlightenment
questions.explanation: The purpose behind painting the various lives of Buddha at Ajanta was to remind the monks of their ideals and the hardships he faced on his journey towards enlightenment.

questions.question: What is distinctive about the color scheme at Ajanta?
options: It is sophisticated with masterful lines
questions.explanation: The colour scheme at Ajanta is sophisticated, and the lines are masterful, showing the high skill of the painters.

questions.question: What was discovered near Roap Village in the Mirzapur region?
options: A painting of a rhinoceros hunted by three men
questions.explanation: In 1881, J. Cockburn found a painting of a rhinoceros hunted by three men in a shelter near Roap Village, along with fossilised rhinoceros bones in the valley of the Ken River.

questions.question: What shape is the rock formation where Ajanta caves are located?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta caves had been excavated in a horse-shoe-shaped bend of rock surface in different periods from 2nd century B.C. to 6th century A.D.

questions.question: How many Chaityagrihas (prayer halls) are at Ajanta?
questions.explanation: Out of 29 caves at Ajanta, five (cave no. 9, 10, 19, 26, and 29) are Chaityagrihas where religious discourses were conducted.

questions.question: What are viharas at Ajanta?
questions.explanation: The majority of the Ajanta caves are viharas or living quarters for the monks, while five are Chaityagrihas (prayer halls).

questions.question: Why have some Ajanta murals been lost?
options: Due to neglect and the ravages of time
questions.explanation: Though all the caves had been painted, many murals have been lost due to neglect and the ravages of time. Only caves 1, 2, 9, 11, 16 and 17 have discernible murals today.

questions.question: What do Bodhisattvas represent in Buddhist tradition?
options: Enlightened beings who delay nirvana through compassion for suffering beings
questions.explanation: Bodhisattvas are enlightened beings or persons who are able to reach nirvana but delay doing so through compassion for suffering beings.

questions.question: What underlines the high sophistication of Ajanta artists?
options: The harmonious lines, combination of jewel and earth tones, and composition
questions.explanation: The harmonious lines, the combination of jewel and earth tones, and the composition of the murals underline the high sophistication of the Ajanta artists.

questions.question: What confirms the ideals of refined man in Padmapani Bodhisattva?
options: His calm fine-featured face, proportionate body, and stance
questions.explanation: The calm, fine-featured face, proportionate body, and stance of Padmapani Bodhisattva confirm the ideals of the refined man set by the ideals of the Bodhisattva.

questions.question: What does the term 'Padmapani' literally mean?
options: Lotus in hand (Padma = lotus, Pani = hand)
questions.explanation: Padmapani literally means 'lotus in hand' - in Sanskrit, Padma is the lotus blossom and Pani is the hand, referring to the blue lotus blossom held in the Bodhisattva's right hand.
